Characteristic analysis of continuous new particle formation events in Hefei: A case study of the May Day holiday in China b Key Lab of Environmental Optics and Technology, Anhui Institute of Optics and Fine Mechanics, Hefei Institutes of Physical Science, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Hefei Studying the characteristics of new particle formation (NPF) is conducive to exploring the impact of atmospheric particulate matter on the climate, environment, and human health. The particle number size distributions (5.6-560 nm) of aerosols were measured using a fast mobility particle sizer (FMPS) from 1 to 11 May 2019. The clean atmosphere was one of the basic conditions for the occurrence of this continuous new particle formation events. It started between 9:00 and 12:00, and it mainly ended after 20:00. The frowth rate (GR) and condensation sink (CS) values in Hefei were 2.98 + 0.97 nm-h “ and (3.0 + 0.4) x 10°“ s “, respectively. Back trajectory clustering analysis revealed that the mass concentration of the air masses from the southeastern part of Henan Province and the southern part of Anhui Province surrounding the study area were relatively high. The analysis results of the potential source contribution function (PSCF) and the concentration weighted trajectory (CWT) methods show that in addition to local pollution, the long-distance transport of pollutants in the Yangtze River Delta (YRD) greatly contributed to the accumulation modal particulate concentration in Hefei. Moreover, the population affected by PM2.5 during the observation period reached 8.19 x 104, accounting for 1.08% to the total population in Hefei. The premature death cases associated with PMz,5 reached 8.35 x 102. This study is helpful to understand the main influencing factors of consecutive NPF events and the health risks of fine particles. New particle formation (NPF) is one of the important sources of at- mospheric ultrafine particles and global cloud condensation nuclei (Kulmala et al., 2004; Gordon et al., 2017). The generation of new particles can significantly increase the reflectivity of clouds, thus affecting the global radiation balance and global climate through cloud physical processes and precipitation (Dinoi et al., 2021). Due to the significant impact of ultrafine particles (less than 100 nm in diameter) on climate, air quality and human health, people’s interest in atmo- NPF events (Shen et al., 2019; Ling et al., 2019; Dinoi et al., 2021; Zhang et al., 2017; Wei et al., 2022). In addition, the environments in which NPF events occur are diverse, such as under cloudy conditions, in clean or polluted environments, and at night (Altst¨adter et al., 2018; Gr¨oß et al., 2018; Wang et al., 2017a). However, due to the complexity of atmospheric nucleation processes, it is still unclear whether NPF for- mation is dominated by one or more different factors (Dall’Osto et al., 2018). Moreover, there are few studies on NPF events over a continuous period of time. Based on observations, an interesting phenomenon involving 11 consecutive days of NPF events occurred during the May Day holiday in Hefei. Investigating this event is of great significance for understanding new particle generation characteristics in the Yangtze River Delta (YRD) region of China. threatened most urban areas in China (Liu et al., 2019; Yin et al., 2015; Zhang et al., 2020). Prolonged exposure to high levels of PM2.5 poses a serious threat to human health, especially respiratory and cardiovas- cular diseases (Xu et al., 2018). Wang et al. (2019) studied the rela- tionship between respiratory microbiota and human respiratory functions. More and more attention has been paid to the quantitative analysis of the estimated mortality risk associated with long-term and short-term PM2.5 exposure (Jiang et al., 2020). Previous research found the NPF event is related to the degree of PM2.5 pollution (Ou et al., 2022). In view of the domestic and foreign concerns about the health effects of fine particles, this article launches an analysis of the patho- genic risk of PM2.5 in Hefei during this continuous new particle gener- ation event. The field campaign conducted in this study was carried out at a station in urban Hefei (117 ◦ 27 ′ E, 31 ◦ 84 ′ N), China, during May 1–11, 2019. The observation station was located on the eastern campus of the University of Science and Technology of China (USTC), which is sur- rounded by residential and commercial areas. The instruments were setup on the top floor of a four-story building. The sample inlet was on the rooftop and was approximately 20 m above the ground level. There was no obvious pollution source around the sampling point.

In this study, a fast mobility particle sizer (FMPS) was used to measure the particle number size distributions during the Labor Day holiday in Hefei in the YRD, China. The gas pollutants (SO2, NO, NO2, and O3) were also used to identify and describe the NPF events. Cluster, the potential source contribution function (PSCF), and the concentration weighted trajectory (CWT) analyses were conducted to investigate the origin of the polluted air masses and the potential sources of the fine particles in Hefei. In addition, the effects of the PM2.5 on health were analyzed using the health exposure-response function method. This study provides new insights into the occurrence and driving of contin- uous NPF, and the prevention and control of PM2.5 pollution in YRD region. A fast mobility particle sizer (FMPS) (model FMPS 3091, TSI Inc., St. Paul, MN, USA) was used to measure the aerosols with dynamic di- ameters ranging from 5.6 nm to 560 nm. Before each measurement, the FMPS was calibrated and cleared using a supporting filter device to ensure the accuracy of the data. The real-time sampling was performed for 24 h, and the sampling time resolution was 1 s. For more information about the instrument, refer to Shen and Cao (2020). The hybrid single-particle Lagrangian integrated trajectory (HYS- PLIT) model developed by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Air Resources Laboratory (NOAA-ARL) has been widely used in air pollutant transportation research (Che et al., 2021; Xu et al., 2018). The HYSPLIT model was used in this study to calculate the 24 h backward trajectory at a height of 500 m during the observation period. The meteorological field used in the model was the reanalyzed data from the National Environmental Prediction Center (NECP), which has a horizontal resolution of 0.5 ◦ × 0.5 ◦ . In this study, the historical meteorological data, including the hourly wind speed (WS), wind direction (WD), temperature (T), and relative humidity (RH), were collected obtained from the Hefei Xinqiao Inter- national Airport station (http://www.wunderground.com/). The gaseous pollutant (SO2, NO2, CO, and O3) and particulate matter (PM: PM2.5 and PM10) data were obtained from the surrounding national observation stations operated by the China National Environmental Monitoring Center (http://www.cnemc.cn). The transport pathways and potential sources of the accumulated modal particles were investigated using cluster analysis, the PSCF method, and the CWT method (Shen and Cao, 2020). To reduce the ef- fect of small values of Nij, the PSCF values and CWT values were multiplied by an arbitrary weight function Wij to better reflect the un- certainty in the values for these cells, and this is referred to as WPSCF (Weighting potential source contribution function) and WCWT (Weighting concentration weighted trajectory) in each model, respec- tively. The model parameters and algorithms of the above three back- ward trajectory analysis methods have been described in detail by Wang et al. (2006) and Hong et al. (2019). The exposure-response function is widely used in many epide- miological studies to estimate the health effects related to air pollution (Xu et al., 2018; Kan and Chen, 2004). Combined with the backward trajectory and the high value distri- bution of the WPSCF and WCWT results, it was concluded that in addition to local pollution, the long-distance transportation of pollutants in the YRD and northern regions contributed significantly to the con- centration of sub-micron particles in Hefei. Finally, the results of the health risk assessment caused by PM2.5 pollution in the Hefei area show that the number of people affected by PM2.5 was 8.19 × 104 during the study period, accounting for 1.08% of Hefei’s population. In this study, three specific causes of death, i.e., respiratory cancer, cardiovascular cancer, and lung cancer, were systematically estimated. In addition, respiratory and cardiovascular hospitalizations, medical and pediatric outpatient clinic treatments, acute and chronic bronchitis cases, and asthma attacks were also estimated. Specifically, the population affected by PM2.5 reached 8.19 × 104, accounting for 1.08% of the total population (7.58 million) in Hefei during the study period. Among the various diseases affected by PM2.5, acute bronchitis had the largest number, accounting for 38.5% of the total number of premature deaths caused by PM2.5, followed by pedi- atric cases (<14 years old), accounting for 34.4% of the total number of patients. During the observation period, the sum of all of the PM2.5 related mortalities was 8.35 × 102 people, accounting for 1.02% of the annual death toll in Hefei and 0.01% of the total population in Hefei. Therefore, the health risks caused by PM2.5 pollution in Hefei should receive more attention. This analysis provides a useful basis for formu- lating air pollution control policies.
